title: Announcement, "Jackie Blum, Peggy Kempton, and Evelyn Silva at American Contemporary Gallery", 1943
medium: Imprinted on thick, textured yellow paper
signed: Imprinted in black ink, lower right corner, sideways:  lustig.
inscribed: Imprinted in rust ink along upper left edge, sideways:  EXHIBIT; in yellow (reserve), across center:  jackie blum/peggy kempton/evelyn silva; in black, across lower third of page:  An exhibition of paintings by Jackie Blum, Peggy Kempton and/Evelyn Silva will open Sunday afternoon, January 10, 1943,/from 3:00 to 7:00. The exhibit will continue until February 6./; in rust:  AMERICAN CONTEMPORARY GALLERY/; in black:  6727 1/2 HOLLYWOOD BOULEVARD, HOLLYWOOD - NO. 1064; Verso, in black, upper left:  jackie blum/peggy kempton/evelyn silva; at center left:  The work of these three young painters has an attrac-/tion for me that painting rarely provides.  Although/personal and intense, they are planned with a dec-/orative logic, usually lacking in works of any expres-/sive power.  This highly personal frontier work in the realm of form, unhampered by too finished a tech-/nique, makes an unwitting contribution to the imper-/sonal tradition of the designer or architect, that, is to/me most valuable.  Sensitive and far from "primitive,"/these small paintings carry large lessons for the more finished painter./Alvin LUSTIG/AMERICAN CONTEMPORARY GALLERY/6727 1/2 HOLLYWOOD BOULEVARD, HOLLYWOOD; in black, upper right corner:  SEC. 562, P.L. & R.
description: Exhibition announcement imprinted in rust and black on yellow ground.  Names of three painters, Jackie Blum, Peggy Kempton, Evelyn Silva appear separately on what appear to be three horizontal, asymmetrically-placed bricks[?], in rust, black, rust respectively,  with rough edged, "broken" ends. Imprinted over the three brick-like shapes is a thin, black arrow-shaped line whose point is right edge, center. Beneath a text block in black explaining exhibition with days, dates, times, beneath this name of gallery and address.  On verso, imprinted in black, on left side, names of artists, block of text by Alvin Lustig, name and location of gallery.
